A recommended title for the ones who are into cinema not only for the summer blockbusters and cheap one-liners. I feel this one is meant for us lot who can appreciate a sincere old-school flick.

4/5

review_title: It warms up nicely, but turns out to be as soulless as a winter apocalypse
review_detailed_main:
The Colony could have flourished with good visual and cast, but it squanders the potential before it enters the second act. The main issue is how stagnant and predictable the plot progresses, screenplay it uses is the very generic template for sci-fi genre. It barely possesses any unique qualities, and by the time the movie is over, it will be either forgettable or interchangeable with any mediocre films.

Story follows the survivors on Colony 7, led by Briggs (Laurence Fishburne). They have been plagued with the dangerous common cold, in which everyone who even shows symptoms are quarantined, possibly exiled or even killed. They also receive strange message from Colony 5, their neighbor colony and must go to examine whether it's real or not. The overall concept holds some promise, but there are far too many boring narratives and stupid behaviors from the characters to fully realize its prospect.

Script is highly foreseeable, down to the sob stories of the survivors, which to the film's credit, would be salvageable if it actually portrays them instead of having guys talk about it. Characters also perform a few needless monologues that don't help setting the tension, they merely drag the movie by a few minutes. Furthermore, many of the characters' decision are moronic, the film tries to convince audience with stress or fear excuse, and even if that's true, it's still stupid by any stretch. This is the equivalent of seeing someone decide to split up in horror flick.

Visual is pretty exceptional, it has good sharp contour and vibrant color. However, most of it are used in ordinary hallway full of pipes or barren wastelands, the most notably landmark is broken bridge which could very well be featured in half dozen other sci-fi films. The actors aren't that bad either, it's just the material is too thin and lacking any suspense for them to capitalize on.

The Colony might have bits that could've worked, but with too predictable execution and uninspiring plot, a visit isn't exactly recommended.

The Colony is one of those movies that seems to fall short of it's potential. It starts off with some interest, the story is appealing, yet it fails to develop it and seems the story is lost midway into the movie, becoming something with really no story, or the little there is, is just not good enough. Not to mention that midway of the movie, seems people are hit by a retarded wave that freezes their brains and ability to think, which cant help but disappoint me. Its a pity, since it could be so much better. I can't rate it better than an OK movie, not one I would go out of my way to watch, but decent for those who enjoy the Post-Apocalypse style.

25 September 2014. This predictable, sci fi survival thriller has the makings of a great movie. The setting, set design, and atmospherics were excellent as depicted in Dark Water (2005), The Numbers Station(2013), and Silent Hill (2006). The plot outline basic, but decent. Yet unlike John Carpenter's remake of The Thing (1982), Colony has a great build up but seemingly loses its way and devolves into a stereotypical, violent chaos with not much in the way of intelligent script writing.

The premise of isolated pockets of humanity in a bleak ice-bound, frozen land, the mysterious SOS message, the lonely, dangerous search, the discovery and even further tidbit of hope all are fabulous in their presentation. Bill Pullman's role and how the script relates him to others is uneasily handled, sometimes distractedly. By the last third of the movie, the lazy hand of reverting to a quick ending is all that's left and even the final rule of "survival" becomes a seemingly flag for failure as if moral depravity really is the ultimate moral goodness.

review_title: Should have been a series, not a movie
Not too bad of a movie
Tedious hokum. This month's film to avoid.

review_detailed_main:
This movie had it all. There was great acting by Laurence Fishburne and Kevin Zegers, sorry to say mediocre from Bill Paxton. I liked that after the slow beginning, the movie quickly went into high adrenaline-mode with tons of action and chase scenes. Even horror aficionados should enjoy this movie. Honestly, this was one of the very few movies I've watched recently on DVD or even at the movies that I can say I'd watch again!

You know how previews usually show you all the best parts of a movie, well not in this case. The plot-line was well thought out, there was vivid imagery as well. The scenery was done very well, with views of how humanity had existed prior. The place these last dregs of humanity resided in is an actual place, so background work did go into it.

review_title: A Dull Story but Powerful Acting Performances and Canadian Scenery
Partially entertaining, but mostly forgettable ripoff.
review_detailed_main:
The Colony offers an interesting premise that may bring back memories of movies such as Ghosts of Mars and Pandorum. Part post apocalyptic, part sci-fi, The Colony is about a bitter future where people need to fight against cold, hunger and sickness for survival, but also against each other.

The first half may not be like much. Both Bill Paxton and Lawrence Fisburne can be the backbone of movies but not in this one. Both are misplaced, misdirected and underused. The watcher will probably fail to connect or care with any of the characters. It is only after the first half where the movie becomes part horror/action, that you'll be interested enough to actually focus.

That and that alone makes this otherwise forgettable and below average movie worth watching.

The subject and potential here were good with compelling dystopian storyline. Also the flu/virus sideline was an interesting juxtaposition for viewing in early 2021. Worthy acting by the leading characters. This was also a bad-guy portrayal for Bill Paxton. A few extra details added to the script would've made for a better film. The build-up towards the finale was decent but the worst part was the very ending showing the foolish unpreparedness of the remaining colonists. In my opinion, worth seeing.

review_title: Good Overall Story - Could've been done better

review_detailed_main: Many bad reviews but I gotta confess - I liked it. True is, The Colony doesn't invent the wheel new and the story told is maybe a little too standard but what we get is a decent post-apocalyptic flick set in a world after a new ice age hit Earth with some action and good production and solid acting. If you like movies like The Book of Eli, The Road or The Day etc. this may be a movie for you - Snowpiercer got a bigger production value and the more crazy storyline, but well, not one of the mentioned movies is imo superb like Max Rockatansky's adventures in the Australian Outback, but all are entertaining. The Colony - a good one-timer for the lover of the world after the great fall.
I enjoyed this movie if I didn't see people calling it a B-movie I would've never known I recommend this movie I believe you'll like it.

So there's Bill Paxton being all tough and mean and Lawrence Fishburn being all in charge and lots of snow and blood and violence. What's not to like?

It's an easy watch that doesn't take a lot of thinking about. I can't say what movies it's like without spoiling it but I'd recommend it to anyone who's open to a small amount of gore.

review_title: typical end of the world fair
review_detailed_main:
It starts out "okay" not the best but like all movies of this genre there is little done to break new ground. Security is one door, when they mount a rescue mission they take two guns and on untested boy (he should have worn a red shirt).

The bad guys several explosion and seem to be able to climb hills faster than the average person can walk. They also have an incredible knowledge of the facility they're attacking. So it seems like being a cannibal give you not only super strength but you can also survive extreme weather conditions track like panther, and your thought process is elevated to new heights.

A typical overthrow of leadership is played out and I'd be surprised if anyone didn't see it coming. The weapons used by the defenders is slap dash at best and considering they could scavenge a whole city you would think someone would at least forge swords or make bows and arrows for protection.

The end was left open for the sequel which I hope never gets made. I know everyone needs a pay check but this one seemed really bad for Fisbourne and Paxton.

review_title: Had a Lot of Promise With Brilliant Ideas All Thrown Away In Replace of A Bloody Battle With Cannibals

review_detailed_main:
I thought came to me, does this look like the same snowpiercer world?

Maybe when the world first started to freeze and people could still walk the earth 🤔 Many crazy stuff could've happened with the climate change.

I can say bad things and good things about this movie. Where to start? OK, the bad ones: except Laurence Fishburne, who is very natural and is a very good actor, the others are under any criticism. The story, as it was screened, is predictable. The film does not have the tension it could have had, with another director and very good actors. Good things: The subject is generous and could have been an extraordinary film directed by, let's say, Stanley Kubrick or Franklin J. Schaffner, the director of "Planet of the Apes" (1968). Unfortunately, they both direct films in another dimension.

review_title: Average but watchable - better than many other B movies
Worthy entry in the sci-fi/action end of the world genre

review_detailed_main:
Forced underground owing to the next ice age, a community tries to survive nature until a savage force gets the colony in it's sights!

Who doesn't like a Post Apocalyptic film, really? Throw in the timeless Lawrence Fishburne, the man would give credibility to a soiled diaper and the versatile veteran, Bill Paxton and the only thing missing is the popcorn! Fishburne and Paxton are flawless in portraying their characters in what can only be described as a launch pad for young and adequate, Kevin Zegers.

Director, Jeff Renfroe has been more involved with TV and although The Colony isn't a bad effort, it lacks that 'gripping' factor. Once the credits role you can't help but shrug and feel let down since the plot had so much potential. It's not a, bad film, it's more of a 'not bad' film. Something to consider watching on DVD if you've run out of choice.

review_title: Beautiful arctic landscapes but not much more
review_detailed_main:
"The Colony" had all the right ingredients for a great science fiction film, but the end result of this movie was disappointing. To jump to the story line briefly, "The Colony" is a movie about a group of humans living in an futuristic setting where Earth has literally froze into a second ice age. They reside in an arctic outpost trying to survive, preserving plants, animals, and other necessities to preserve life. Things turn weary where another outpost sends out a distress signal. Without spoiling the film, I will just say that "The Colony" is a lackluster, B grade science fiction film at best. And that makes me sad because I really wanted to like this movie. Bill Paxton, a fantastic veteran actor of epic films like, "Aliens" and "Apollo 13" played a completely hate-able character in this film that was just too out of character for him. Laurence Fishburne had some decent screen time but also came off a bit short compared to his previous performances like in "The Matrix" and "Event Horizon". I don't think it was either actors faults but more so these cookie-cutter type characters they had to play. As far as the main role goes, it was played by Canadian actor Kevin Zegers. He was decent in this film but not the best choice in my opinion for the lead role. He just doesn't have that on screen spark for me.

Besides focusing on the two big names in this film, the rest of the film just fell short. The movie (unlike other films) seemed to end to short and quickly. I was expecting far more. The character development was very poor as well and the whole angle of this movie just a bit off. This movie ended up being some freakshow horror film in the end and I think it it was focused on being a survival/adventure film more with a less hate-able role from Paxton, I think this film would have been great. Lastly on the plus side, this film does got some good camera work and visuals. Very pretty arctic scenery and the underground colonies look nice. But other than the visuals, I can't say much about the rest of this film. It was pretty lackluster. Regardless, I do think it's worth a watch if you like sci fi fans and are a fan of Fishburne and Paxton (even though their roles weren't that great). But chalk this one up as a "rental only" because in the end, this movie is just pretty crappy.

Ok, I admit, 'The Colony' isn't really something we haven't seen before, but there's no denying this is a very enjoyable action horror.

'The Colony' gave me a 'Day after Tomorrow' meets 'The Thing' feel - just without The Thing's grotesque creations off course. So, we've seen this a hundred times before; people just trying to survive in an underground bunker in a post-apocalyptic world. The visuals are not the best and maybe not always believable, but at least there's a good story here and characters I care about. The film only really gains momentum around the halfway mark, once the rescue team reaches Colony 5.

The moment they reach Colony 5, the film accelerates to bring us an action-packed horror adventure in a frozen world. I loved it. It was creepy, suspenseful, thrilling, exciting. There were horror, explosions, fighting, shooting. And off course, all hell broke loose during the film's heart pounding final act. It does end very abruptly, though. I wanted it to run at least another twenty minutes or so. Nevertheless, I enjoyed this.

review_title: Feeble, derivative and really hard to sit through
review_detailed_main: Where do they get these useless directors ... This is about as accomplished as a movie on the SciFi channel Whoever made this should be embarrassed and banned from having anything to do with film ever again ... There is no excuse ... This was rubbish There isn't one idea or scene in this wopping great flop that you haven't seen before 100 times ... And its usually done better It must have looked dull on paper even before it went into production so it just proves how clueless the producers of this garbage are ... Its not even competent enough to give you a few laughs at its badness Really this is just such a dead in the water joke of a movie that you seriously shouldn't waste the 90 minutes of your life Do the washing up instead ... Its more entertaining

Love this movie! Nail biting, on the edge of your seat, yelling at the tv kinda movie! I would have gave it a 10/10 if the scenes in the snow and cold were more realistic.... (Being able to see their breath, rosy cheeks ect...) Other than that... It's a great movie!!

The premise is interesting. Mankind created machines to combat global warming which backfired and triggered an ice age. And even if you can suspend you disbelief so that even a million of these machines to do that, you're left with one after the other impossibilities that grate on you as you watch.

It's acted well, especially by L. Fishborn, but the directing and cinematography don't fit. The first half plays like an art film, the second like a heavy metal music video.

The event that sets the plot in motion is to its inevitable end is ridiculous.

On the plus, this is an evolution of the zombie film. Watching from that point of view, you might enjoy it.

I really liked the idea of this movie and it started out pretty good but quickly went downhill. There were a few decent parts, and you will like this movie if you are into the lame slasher kinda zombie movies but it just wasn't for me. I do not like the intense action, shaking camera, followed by over used tag lines. "Come and get it!" Pretty poor acting especially by Laurence Fishburne. Not very believable and way to much suspense building up to what is already expected. Dramatic over used score that we have all heard a thousand times before in every other slasher/zombie movie. Some of the action shots and effects were so bad it was embarrassing. Punches that weren't any where close to the intended target. Axe hits with no force behind them at all.
This movie stinks. Waste of time. Simply horrible, horrible, horrible. Horrible, horrible.

review_title: Exactly what I wanted, and then a little bit more.
Not terrible just a little too slow to stay interested in. I would recommend the movie Whiteout over this. I say C+
review_detailed_main: "We used to live and die by the rules we made but the rules, like everything else we made, are breaking down." After a new ice age hits cities are gone. Now people live in underground areas called colonies. In colony 7 things are run pretty tight because of the rules they have set up. When they receive a distress signal from another colony Sam (Zegers) and Briggs (Fishburne) decide to venture out to see if they can help. What they find is something no one expected and they must not only escape but find a way back to their home safely. Judging by the trailer I was looking forward to this one because I liked Day After Tomorrow and that's what the trailer reminded me of. While the idea was similar the movie wasn't. The first thing I have to say is that the trailer was exciting and tense, the movie wasn't. I found myself really struggling to stay interested in this and waiting for it to be over. The "twist" while not unexpected was a little bit of a surprise but not interesting enough to change the way I felt about the movie. To me the movie Whiteout was much more interesting and I would recommend that one over this. Overall, nothing terrible but just a little too slow and unexciting to stay interested in. I give it a C+.

review_title: One of the worst movie ever...
review_detailed_main: One of the worst movie ever... I really don't know where to start to describe it... Just don't buy it!

review_title: Canadians prove they can make a dud as well!

review_detailed_main:
Maybe I'm just a sucker for post apocalyptic movies.

THE COLONY doesn't reinvent the wheel but it manages to tick off all the 'must have' boxes for this genre of movie. You can nit pick about individuals scenes or elements but I think as a finished product it holds up quite well.

The pacing was deliberate and measured although I can see how some people might interpret that as slow or dragging.

I was impressed that the movie chose to hold off on some of the worst excesses of action films, its hard to stage fight scenes dressed in three layers of winter clothing.

well this movie was a waste of time...storyline was OK, Fishburn and Bill Paxton but it was unfinished I think. There was so much more they could have done with it. For example..why was the world covered in snow...why did those freaks turned into wild animals? Not because they were hungry?...the ending was crap..but that it just my humble opinion:)I think if they had just explained a bit more about the weather stations it would have made a huge difference. Instead they created a mix between mad max ( indeed..someone mentioned it ) and ice planet. The characters are not really explained, like Kai, And where did they get their bullets and stuff to kill everyone with a sniffle? I would be dead a long long time ago;)

This movie had a good premise and a strong cast. Ultimately however I feel a lack of attention to detail and story telling let the movie down and moving it into B-movie category. Watching The Colony I was reminded quite a bit of Ghosts Of Mars - which if you haven't seen please watch instead of this. Despite strong characters in the roles such as Fishburn and Paxton - even the lead character Zergers was a good convincing lead - I found some plot elements ridiculously predictable as well as some ensuing problems becoming unintelligent, clichéd and illogical. The survivors struggling in their confined space and paranoia and the drama of this position ultimately fell to a feeble plot device. Place brain in neutral this wasn't as dramatic as hoped.

review_title: A poor unimaginative movie for in between.
The Colony is gloomy and downright boring. I shut it off at 46 minutes in
review_detailed_main:
(Credit IMDb) Forced underground by the next ice age, a struggling outpost of survivors must fight to preserve humanity against a threat even more savage than nature.

If a movie fails to interest me 40 minutes in, I tend to shut it off, sometimes sooner. I gave this one a chance to recover a little bit, but wound up being constantly bored. I'm rather tired of "post-apocalyptic" survivor films. This does nothing to reinvent the genre what so ever. Laurence Fishburne is an excellent actor, but he looks like he's eaten one too many big mac's. Kevin Zegers is far more talented than the material he seems to get. Frozen & Transamerica have proved my point. I also didn't really warm up to any of the characters. I was just bored silly, and couldn't find anything worthwhile to finish the movie. I won't blame you if you don't find this review helpful, I sure wouldn't. All I can tell you is that it wasn't my cup of tea

2/10

review_title: If you like Sci-Fi action watch this movie
review_detailed_main:
It is sad that totally usable Sci-Fi movies are rated 5+. People that made this movie had limited budget, but managed to create decent action thriller. Yes, the script is predictable, yes some acting is poor, yes this movie has nothing new, but still I enjoyed watching it and I can honestly recommend to viewers seeking decent Sci-Fi / action / horror flicks.

Post production is done well and there is no ugly or cheap looking scenes in the film. Characters are acting stupid, but most probably so are real people if you live earth after new ice age. With some more hours with scrip and this would be a great and entertaining movie. I hope that Jeff Renfroe will get decent budget for his next movie.

review_title: It was going ok until the dreaded shakycam started...
review_detailed_main: The first 50 minutes were going well, then the shakycam started and I felt sick trying to watch it. I wonder what happened in the end?

Released in 2013, "The Colony" is a post-apocalyptic movie about life in North America after the next ice age hits. Laurence Fishburne stars as the leader of an underground colony with Bill Paxton (R.I.P.) as his problematic assistant. Kevin Zegers plays a younger guy who rises to the challenge when contact with a neighboring colony is lost and a trio treks the winter wilderness to check on the status of its inhabitants.

My wife watched this movie on DVD before I did and, knowing it was some kind of wintery post-apocalyptic movie, I naturally asked her: "Are there mutants in it?" By "mutants" I meant, of course, any number of antagonists typical to the genre – zombies, cannibals, diseased tramps, monsters, etc. She didn't respond, but I knew the answer and was right. So this is a hackneyed post-apocalyptic movie; the question is: Does it rise to the challenge within that increasingly stale sci-fi/horror/action genre? Is there something about it that's fresh and invigorating?

The answer is "no." There are obvious elements of numerous similar flicks, like "The Day After Tomorrow" (2004), "Day of the Dead" (1985), "The Thing" (1982), "Aliens" (1979), "Aliens" (1986) and the first two "Planet of the Apes" movies (1968, 1970). That said, "The Colony" is solid for what it is, which is helped by the fact that it doesn't overstay its welcome at 94 minutes. The CGI backdrops are convincing, albeit a little cartoonish, and I found myself drawn into the world of the characters. It's a good thing Charlotte Sullivan is on hand as the protagonist's babe, though.

The dramatic first half of the movie is a slow-build to the action-packed second half with its revelation of the main villain(s), which is underwhelming when revealed (I'm not going to give it away). I will say that there is a character played by Dru Viergever who's garbed like Pinhead's little brother or perhaps a rejected vampire from "Underworld" (2003). Whatever the case, I chuckled a few times upon eyeing his stereotypical menacing expressions/antics.

The movie's further brought down by the predictable political correctness wherein the sage leader is a seasoned black man and his unofficial second-in-command is a moral, intelligent & beautiful white woman. These two are naturally contrasted by the selfish and sociopathic "aging white guy," a symbol of all that is wrong with the world (rolling my eyes).

A Canadian production, the movie was shot at some defunct underground power plant in North Bay, Canada, with (I presume) establishing shots from Lapland, Finland, and studio work done in Toronto. DIRECTOR: Jeff Renfroe. WRITERS: Renfroe, Patrick Tarr, Pascal Trottier & Svet Rouskov. Atticus Mitchell has a small role.

GRADE: C

ADDITIONAL COMMENTARY ***SPOILER ALERT*** (Don't read unless you've seen the movie):

The aforementioned "mutants" turn out to be merely "humans gone feral," as Fishburne's character describes them. Cracked cannibals or not, wouldn't their priority be acquiring food supplies rather than senseless slaughter? Moreover, does it make sense to forgo a good take of fresh meat to wander the ruthless winter wilderness searching for even more food when it's not a for sure endeavor? Do farmers slaughter all their livestock at once? There are too many logical holes.

I guess our world" leaders" used this as a playbook for their nefarious purposes. Another scare em tactic that's worked for the Sheeple.🙄 It's a cold,plain and simple but apparently it's enough to give you two choices,firing squad or freeze to death out in the badlands. I like Bill Paxton and Laurence Fishburn too but I guess everyone makes bad choices. Couldnt watch this waste of time movie. Fauci probably loved this and got the script to use,making his mandates. They should have cast him in this atrocity Dr Evil lol! Anyway,I wouldn't waste my time on the fear factor of a movie. There's enough of it on the (non) news if that's your cup of tea.

i really didn't know what to expect with this film, looked good on trailer but like a TV movie. it really wasn't. great acting and good solid story. no cheap thrills or cheesy lines. just a story explained properly!! great film!!!! Laurence Fishbourne is a legend and doesn't over play his role few new faces involved but the best actor is bill Paxton. he always delivers and doesn't do bad films. the story is convincing and delivers well, testament to the director because this would have been worse had tom cruise starred in it. oh wait! he did try in oblivion which was Hollywoods version which was for simple minded folk. This is a cracking film. thrills scary and entertaining to the last minute.

The Colony (2013) takes us to a post-apocalyptic, snow-covered Earth where survival is a constant struggle. Set in a world plagued by perpetual winter and disease, the film follows a small group of survivors in an underground bunker as they grapple with dwindling resources, food shortages, and the omnipresent threat of disease. When they lose contact with another colony, a small team sets out into the frozen wasteland to investigate, uncovering horrors they weren't prepared for.

On the plus side, The Colony has a solid premise, promising a mix of sci-fi and horror that could appeal to fans of dystopian survival narratives. Laurence Fishburne and Kevin Zegers bring a steady presence to their roles, doing their best to add depth to somewhat one-dimensional characters. The set design effectively conveys a cold, gritty atmosphere that matches the bleakness of the plot. The stark visuals and suspenseful moments give a strong impression of isolation, adding to the movie's dark tone.

However, The Colony suffers from some drawbacks that hold it back. The script often feels underdeveloped, leaving intriguing themes like humanity's adaptability and the cost of survival barely explored. Additionally, the pacing can be sluggish, with a lack of substantial character development or emotional depth. The movie's horror element relies heavily on predictable jump scares rather than building genuine tension, which may disappoint genre enthusiasts looking for a more layered thrill. The plot also feels rushed towards the end, with an overly familiar climax that wraps up too conveniently.

Overall, The Colony is a mixed bag. It delivers some engaging moments and visuals that hint at what could have been a more complex story. For casual fans of post-apocalyptic thrillers, it may provide a couple of hours of moderate entertainment. But for those seeking a film with richer themes or more inventive storytelling, The Colony falls a bit short.

review_title: What an awful and stupid ending to an otherwise OK film
review_detailed_main: Despite the bad reviews out there, I believe the movie progresses somewhat convincingly (with a few mishaps here and there), but eventually falls apart with a very foolish ending. So, if a good story is one that happens to be told decently from the very beginning till the end, this is clearly not it. In the end, I felt thoroughly cheated and my time wasted. Otherwise, good cinematography and believable sets and surroundings through the 2/3s of the movie.

review_title: Why do characters make such bad choices?
review_detailed_main:
One of those films with a few of key points in the narrative where any reasonable and even panicking person would have made more logical decisions, and thus averted unneeded mayhem. But then we wouldn't have a film full of action and blood, would we, which is what many are after.

It's better when characters are up against threats while making logical choices rather than succumbing to their stupidity. Quite unsatisfying. The primary villains in this would have been easy to deal with.

Ignore negative feedback!!! This movie had me on the edge of my seat n I didn't get up to make a cuppa!!!!! Really really brilliant n thought provoking cos another ice age may happen 🙈 !!! review_title: No story, plus no background, plus stereotypes, equals boring
Starts good, but then looses steam

review_detailed_main:
The best thing in this movie are opening and end credits. There is a good story waiting to be told in this setting, it just wasn't this one. No focus, no character development, no depth of any kind, and not shallow enough to actually be enjoyable. I'm trying to think of a good thing to say, and I guess that would be the atmosphere and initial setup. Unfortunately, it goes nowhere from there. And this is the writing part, direction wasn't too bad, given that the pace was maintained quite well, but can't do much with with a script that has not one original word in it.

Watch Snowpiercer instead, so sorry to even put these two movies in the same category...

After so many let-downs during lockdown it was refreshing to find a film that entertained. The story, directing and acting were great. And I sat in the edge of my seat during some of the tense moments. A couple of things could have been better but in the world of Sci Fi I try to immerse myself in that world. review_title: Man-made laws can sometimes be violated for survival.
review_detailed_main: Man-made laws can sometimes be violated for survival. The 2013 Hollywood film directed by Jeff Renfroe is a magnificent survival thriller film set in just over an hour and a half. The whole world was devastated by the snow. Many people formed a few underground colonies and raised their own food grains, poultry, and rabbits for meat. Even a minor illness can infect others. So infected people may leave the colony or be shot dead under colonial law. Such colonies are invaded by a group of human beings who have become cannibals without food. Thus, the film is about their struggle for survival. The film presents us with a great visual feast. A film that can guarantee you to look bold.

review_title: Good movie but they forgot to end it.
review_detailed_main: My pet peeve is when movies just end without wrapping up and leave it to your imagination. I did enjoy the movie. The storyline was good, but they could have gone a bit further to finish it. If you don't mind movies that leave you hanging, give it a go.

review_title: We live and die by the rules

review_detailed_main:
The Colony is directed by Jeff Renfroe (HAVEN, ALMOST HUMAN & BEAUTY AND THE BEAST) so he has a good eye for visuals, as you can see through his latest film. Originally this film was going to be a big budget ensemble cast piece, but thankfully they used big names & used the budget for the visuals. This amazing apocalyptic sci-fi horror has everything in it.

It stars Kevin Zegers (Adam Green's FROZEN), Laurence Fishburne, & Bill Paxton both of which have acted in their far share of the sci-fi, action & horror genre. Kevin Zegers plays SAM, a almost anti-hero character who doesn't find his place till later on in the film but through his eyes & perspective we see that world needs him in more ways than one. Laurence Fishburne & Bill Paxton play two ex-soldiers Briggs and Mason who team up early on to start a colony of survivors during this whiteout that covers the earth. Both are so different as one is a born leader, the other just wants to lead but both bring so much to their characters that they immerse you into the icy hell that it's hard to see who is right and who is wrong.

In the future, Earth is covered in an Ice Age. The survivors live in facilities underground named Colonies, ergo the name. When people from Colony 5 release a distress signal, the leader of Colony 7 Briggs (played by Fishburne) organizes an expedition with Sam (Zegers) and Graydon (played by Atticus Mitchell who brings a good level of faux bravery & fear to the role) to investigate what has happened to their neighboring colonists. Briggs leaves the scientist Kai (played by the beautiful Charlotte Sullivan) in charge of the group, disappointing his former friend Mason (Paxton).

Walking for days, they finally reach the facility where the fifty said persons reside and they find only one survivor - Leland (played brilliantly by Julian Richings of CUBE & Wrong Turn) so scared to death that he's locked himself in a room deep in the facility. They soon come to realize that something far worse than the cold is hunting humans. The visuals and the cinematography are amazing especially considering that this is the first movie to be shot at the decommissioned NORAD (North American Aerospace Defense Command) base in North Bay, Ontario, Canada.

The interior shots of the base gives the isolation and claustrophobic feel much like that of the original ALIEN film. The exterior shots which were mainly used with green screen but real snow to give the true effects of the cold hell they had to endure had beautiful destruction and chaos, quite a reminiscence of THE DAY AFTER TOMORROW meets THE THING.

The tension builds amazingly well also, not just because of the trek and the weather conditions they have to endure but claustrophobia plays a huge part in this film. The tension also meets with a few good shocks of realism as well due to the human condition and what one does to survive in any condition of despair.

This film has a touch of several great nods to it especially considering the budget they had. It gives nods to (some I mentioned earlier) MAD MAX, THE THING, THE DAY AFTER TOMORROW, as well as THE HILLS HAVE EYES. The solid tension build up, the acting, the visuals all are top notch.

I highly recommend this film.

review_title: HALF WAY TRHOUGH I STARTED CHATTING WITH MY GF INSTEAD
review_detailed_main:
Halg way through I knew I was screwed so I started chatting with my gf instead. I watched the left part later but I clearly shouldn't have.

There's no clear storyline in the movie and the scenes just get extremely dull and boring after the half way mark. Everything is also very predictable.

SKIP INSTEAD

Don't get me wrong, I kind of admire this film. With a very limited budget of 16 million, it manages to give us visuals and settings easily on par with Hollywood blockbusters. The apocalyptic tundra spreads out in front of you frozen to the bone and you can really feel the chill setting in.

Unfortunately the rest of the film fails to impress. Laurence Fishburne is the only actor worth mentioning and even then the script doesn't give him much to work with. The rest are mainly painfully average and don't give us anything to remember them by.

Then there's the script which offers us what we absolutely have to have for us to call this film a passable experience. When I tell you that it's an ice age apocalypse with two colonies struggling to survive together, you can pretty much guess what will happen. The story doesn't deviate away from the basic scripture at all and every single turn is easily predictable and something we have seen hundreds of times before.

Honestly, I'm more disappointed than I'm angry. There is promise here. The visuals are impressive given the budget, and even some of the action is above average. If only it had had something to call its own, I would have been able to recommend this, but as it is, there are far better films out there.

review_title: If only the script matched the set

review_detailed_main: Nothing special and nothing different, always the same story...bla bla bla....the 'bad guys' are very similar to '30 days of night'....almost a waste of time

An ice age has wiped out most of humanity, the last remaining survivors form small colonies, and trt to survive sickness, a virus that threatens to wipe out everyone. A distress call from a nearby colony brings a whole new level of threat.

I'll take into account the fact that this was a B movie when I do my review, clearly not a big budget blockbuster, more a c list sci fi clunker.

It's not bad film as such, but it's a close run thing. I liked the visuals, liked the acting and I felt it had a sense of atmosphere. The main problem, the story sucked, it just wasn't very interesting, it offered absolutely nothing new.

A good start, average middle, and an ending that came so abruptly, it hardly felt like a conclusion, it honestly felt like they simply ran out of either time or budget.

You never feel that you're into it, there's a lot happening, but it all feels disjointed, it doesn't flow. There are some nice action scenes, and the alien beings look pretty good.

I thought Dru Viergever was rather good as the leader of the alien marauders, he certainly looked the part, he had an imposing presence.

5/10.

I watched this movie with low expectations after checking the IMDb rating but the fact that Fishburne has a role convinced me to watch it in the end.

I have to say how surprised I am about the general feedback. It was really enjoyable with a suspenseful atmosphere and it was actually quite scary at some points which I wasn't expecting! I'm a fan of this genre and the scary is not "ghost" scary but a real kind of terror you'd feel if you were in the situation.

I was expecting it to be a typical B kind of movie but the general atmosphere was everything other than that.

The main character reminded me of Zac Efron all the time but I suppose that is highly irrelevant, just saying!

review_detailed_main: Ignore the bad reviews, this is a great film. Atmospheric, bloody, dark, good plot and well acted. I've watched it 3 times over the last year or so. Highly recommend.

I found this piece of crap searching for the Emma Watson film, Colonia, and decided to give it a try since it was included on Amazon Prime and I generally like Laurence Fishburne. I tried to get into it by mocking how bad it is, to enjoy it in the 'so bad it's good' sense, but it is so bad it's bad, not good. I still gave it two stars because, believe it or not, it is much better than some of the other (many) total pieces of crap that are included on Amazon Prime. The set design and wardrobe are probably the best aspects of it. The score blatantly rips off Maria and Autumn Leaves; the makeup department is desperately trying to justify its existence (and failing). Some of the scenes, in terms of the decisions the characters make, are so preposterous that I became angry while watching this film. It probably could've actually been good with a different writer and a different director. It's a shame that talented actors and production crews are having to settle for this kind of utter crap these days. Most of the movies included on Amazon Prime probably should never have been made.

It's just got nothing going for it. It's really a case of the selfish haves wanting to be exclusive towards the have-nots. A pointless movie with no appeal at all. I was just waiting for it to finish. And the ending is what do we do now? We walk. Sure like that's going to work. Idiots. A disturbingly bad movie, much like a zombie film. Cut off the head FTW. Hell Yeah!!

Greetings from Lithuania.

If you like these Sci-Fi flicks, bloody, scary at the moments than "The Colony" is not to be missed one.

review_title: Better than many are giving it credit for...
review_detailed_main:
Solid film with decent characters and a scary arch enemy.

30 Days Night, meets Day After Tomorrow, meets I Am Legend.

Ending was a bit like it ran out of budget, but otherwise a good film.

I liked the dystopian / climate change apocalypse aesthetic and the digging in to the backstory in places... less interested in the romantic sideline, but love what Laurence Fishburne brought to the table. It did set up very simply for a sequel but I guess that never happened. Run time was a lull short, ie it could have gone deeper in places, but perhaps it benefits from not trying to outstay it's welcome.

5.3 on IMDB gave me pause to whether I should watch it or not, but I'm pleased I did.

An intelligent script and excellent direction make The Colony one of the few effective cautionary tales regarding climate change produced since The Day After. Tense, exciting, and at times horrifying, this film succeeds in bringing the consequences of global climate chaos home to a disinterested audience. There is no possible way anyone who experiences this important motion picture can turn away in abject indifference any longer. Overwhelming in its imagery and emotionally raw in its breathtaking prescience, this is a motion picture that should be shown in every young person's classroom. Laurence Fishburne gives a performance of a lifetime here and is supported by an outstanding cast. Pay attention to the message and you will understand why the issues depicted in this movie are the most significant of our time. That is the unrelenting impact which is indeed The Colony.
